--- title: 'STAT 118: Notes P' subtitle: | | Webscraping Text with `rvest` | ![](https://rvest.tidyverse.org/logo.png){width=10%} author: 'Emily Malcolm-White' institute: 'Middlebury College' format: html: toc: TRUE code-overflow: wrap embed-resources: true execute: eval: FALSE --- ::: {.cell hash='118_P_Webscraping_Text_Notes--1-_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_4e9a6d32d9e39aeea322f4c1ea3c8531'} ```{.r .cell-code} #LOAD PACKAGES library(tidyverse) library(rvest) ``` ::: # Webscraping Text Let's look at the [top 50 feature films in the first 7 months of 2023 listed on IMBD](https://www.imdb.com/search/title/?title_type=feature&year=2023-01-01,2023-07-31) ::: {.cell hash='118_P_Webscraping_Text_Notes--1-_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_8e1999668e8c80af5ad0338e40ebe665'} ```{.r .cell-code} URL <- read_html("https://www.imdb.com/search/title/?title_type=feature&year=2023-01-01,2023-07-31") ``` ::: Notice that the data for all these films isn't housed inside a `` element! ## Titles For example, check out the first few lines of html code for Oppenheimer: ```{}

1. Oppenheimer (2023)

``` In this case, we want to look for the class `lister-item-header` AND then pull the text inside the `` (link) tag. `html_elements(".lister-item-header a")` :::callout-tip In this case, we want ALL titles so we used `html_elements()`. If we had only wanted the first title we would have used `html_element()` ::: Scrape IMBD for the titles of the 50 most popular feature films in the first 7 months of 2023. ::: {.cell hash='118_P_Webscraping_Text_Notes--1-_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_2c9f4cb13a9cf4652ee1ce771c43e7e9'} ```{.r .cell-code} title_data <- URL %>% html_elements(".lister-item-header a") %>% html_text() title_data ``` ::: ## Runtime Scrape IMBD for the runtime of the 50 most popular feature films so far in 2023. Check out the relevant HTML code for Oppenheimer: ```{}

R | 180 min | Biography, Drama, History

``` In this case, we need to reference the class `text-muted` AND the class `runtime`. ::: {.cell hash='118_P_Webscraping_Text_Notes--1-_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_ed53fca5c36da84e6f3b10b78f102291'} ```{.r .cell-code} URL %>% html_nodes(".text-muted .runtime") %>% html_text() ``` ::: Alternatively, we could have called class `text-muted` AND the 3rd span, but it's easier and likely more accurate to ask for the class `runtime` in case `runtime` is missing for some reason. Maybe we want to keep the `min` on the end, but it forces it into being a stringr rather than a number which makes it difficult to sort or filter. ::: {.cell hash='118_P_Webscraping_Text_Notes--1-_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_056bf6eddb247782eb7530c96c956575'} ```{.r .cell-code} library(readr) # need this package for parse_number() ``` ::: ![Artwork by @allisonhorst](https://cdn.myportfolio.com/45214904-6a61-4e23-98d6-b140f8654a40/4fd04f07-7404-4371-832c-c04ff9a6e069_rw_1920.png?h=2bd0f0330dc94ccbbb49766ed7f80b8b){width=50%} ::: {.cell hash='118_P_Webscraping_Text_Notes--1-_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_92e5602f4bb3dd05d880c571cbcd2e1b'} ```{.r .cell-code} runtime_data <- URL %>% html_nodes(".text-muted .runtime") %>% html_text() %>% parse_number() %>% #this picks out only the numbers (and drops characters, in this case, "mins") as.numeric() runtime_data ``` ::: ## Ratings Scrape IMBD for the ratings of the 50 most popular feature films in the first 7 months of 2023. Check out the relevant HTML code for Oppenheimer: ```{}
8.6
``` Let's scrape it! ::: {.cell hash='118_P_Webscraping_Text_Notes--1-_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_41c9d585960daf07ff944ac991f5f8bd'} ```{.r .cell-code} rating_data <- URL %>% html_elements(".ratings-imdb-rating strong") %>% html_text() %>% as.numeric() rating_data ``` ::: :::callout-warning Notice that there are only 49 ratings listed, not 50! There is no way to figure out which one is missing besides doing it by hand... Which one is it? Once we figure out which one is it is, we should should add a blank element for the rating for that movie using the `append` function. `rating_data <- append(rating_data, values=FALSE, after=11)` ::: It's Killers of the Flower Moon (#32)! ::: {.cell hash='118_P_Webscraping_Text_Notes--1-_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-8_7ec29e715617c69665d41887daa0cc39'} ```{.r .cell-code} rating_data <- append(rating_data, values=NA, after=31) ``` ::: Notice how it is the correct length (50) now! ## Number of Votes Scrape IMBD for the number of votes of the 50 most popular feature films in the first 7 months of 2023. Relevant code for Oppenheimer: ```{}

Votes: 391,689

``` Let's scrape it! ::: {.cell hash='118_P_Webscraping_Text_Notes--1-_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-9_6e8ca085327adef63d71c469c86c3934'} ```{.r .cell-code} votes_data <- URL %>% html_elements(".sort-num_votes-visible span:nth-child(2)") %>% html_text() %>% parse_number() %>% as.numeric() votes_data ``` ::: :::callout-warning Same issue as before! We were supposed to have 50 but only got 49. It's Killers of the Flower Moon (#32), again! ::: {.cell hash='118_P_Webscraping_Text_Notes--1-_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-10_56afa524171c340f410c0328d22f9bbb'} ```{.r .cell-code} votes_data <- append(votes_data, values=NA, after=31) ``` ::: ::: ## Metascore Scrape IMBD for the number of votes of the 50 most popular feature films in the first 7 months of 2023. Relevant code for Oppenheimer: ```{}
88 Metascore
``` Let's scrape it! ::: {.cell hash='118_P_Webscraping_Text_Notes--1-_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-11_3a896f6a1ffa93ffb16c896d0896fc35'} ```{.r .cell-code} metascore_data <- URL %>% html_elements(".metascore") %>% html_text() %>% parse_number() %>% as.numeric() metascore_data ``` ::: :::callout-warning Yikes! Now we only have 41 when we should have 50. We *could* manually go through and figure out which 9 are missing or we could reassess how important the metascore data is to us... ::: # Combining it all together into a data frame! We can combine all this data into one data frame: ::: {.cell hash='118_P_Webscraping_Text_Notes--1-_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-12_cc90a5ec5abc30f7e8720f1fedf35e8a'} ```{.r .cell-code} movies <- data.frame(Title = title_data, Runtime = runtime_data, Rating = rating_data, Votes = votes_data ) movies ``` ::: Make a list OR Make a plot! ::: {.cell hash='118_P_Webscraping_Text_Notes--1-_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-13_b939f2062561e793d6888006f82aa0a6'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(movies, aes(x=runtime_data, y=rating_data)) + geom_point() + theme_minimal() + xlab("Runtime (in minutes)") + ylab("IMDB Rating") ``` :::
